titleStmt.title: Influence of alloying elements on mechanical and electronic properties of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) refractory high entropy alloys

analytic.title: Influence of alloying elements on mechanical and electronic properties of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) refractory high entropy alloys

biblStruct.note: Received 1 July 2020; Received in revised form 4 August 2020; Accepted 5 August 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High entropy alloys First-principle calculation Mechanical properties Phase structure Elastic properties Electronic structure

div.p: NbMoTaW refractory high entropy alloy (RHEA) has shown great potential applications for high temperature components due to its high temperature mechanical strength. However, the brittleness at room temperature hinders its engineering application and further development. To overcome this deficiency, refractory alloying elements with melting temperatures over 1850 • C, i.e., Cr, Zr, V, Hf, and Re, were chosen to enhance the mechanical performance of NbMoTaW RHEA in the present work. The effects of refractory alloying elements on the strength and ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA were investigated via a combination of theory and experiment. To be specific, the first-principle calculations based on density functional theory were employed to predict the mechanical properties of the alloyed NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs and explain the alloying effect from the atomic and electronic level. Moreover, the phase structures of the alloyed RHEAs were determined based on the formation enthalpy and cohesive energy, as well as some empirical parameters, such as the average valence electron concentration VEC and atomic size difference δ. In combination with the experimental results, the calculated elastic constants and modulus indicated that most of these alloying elements enhanced the strength of NbMoTaW RHEA, while only Zr-alloying significantly improved the ductility. The strengthening mechanism of different elements was well analyzed based on the total and partial density of states, overlapping Mulliken population, charge density contour, and atomic distance. The improvement of the ductility for Zralloying was attributed to the formation of Zr-Zr metallic bonds in the alloyed NbMoTaWX RHEAs. The theoretic predictions were confirmed by the experimental investigations. The present work provides a good guidance for design and construction of NbMoTaW RHEA.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High entropy alloys (HEAs), firstly reported by Yeh et al., are a kind of novel structure materials breaking through the conventional alloy design concept [1][2][3]. Composed of five to thirteen elements with equiatomic or near equiatomic content, HEAs are inclined to form single-phase solid solution structure, such as face-centered cubic (FCC), body-centered cubic (BCC) or close-packed hexagonal (HCP) [4][5][6]. Generally, HEAs are considered to have high entropy effects, lattice distortion effect, slow diffusion effect and cocktail effect [7,8]. They own excellent mechanical properties and have great application prospects. Particularly, refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs), composed of refractory elements, such as Nb, Ta, Mo, W, have high temperature resistance and outstanding high temperature strength [9][10][11][12]. They are considered to be new high temperature alloys for higher temperature applications that exceeding the serving temperature of Ni-based high-temperature alloys. For instance, the firstly reported RHEAs, Nb 25 Mo 25 Ta 25 W 25 and V 20 Nb 20 Mo 20 Ta 20 W 20 [13,14], possess BCC single-phase solid solution structure, and have high temperature stability up to 1600 • C. Importantly, their yield strength maintains 405 MPa and 477 MPa up to 1600 • C. It should be noted that the mechanical strength of Nb 25 Mo 25 Ta 25 W 25 alloy was significantly improved after adding alloying element V, demonstrating that alloying enhancement is an effective method to strengthen RHEAs as it works in the traditional alloys. Though Nb 25 Mo 25 Ta 25 W 25 RHEA has excellent high temperature performance, its ductility is quite poor at room temperature, which hinders the alloy's engineering application. Some investigations have been done to improve the ductility and strength of Nb 25 Mo 25 Ta 25 W 25 RHEAs by alloying with V, Ti, Re and Cu [13][14][15][16][17][18][19]. For example, the yield strength of NbMoTaW RHEA at room temperature was improved from 1058 MPa to 1246 MPa by V alloying while it still maintained the low fracture strain [14]. Ti alloying obviously enhanced both the strength (from 1058 MPa to 1343 MPa) and ductility (from 2.6% to 14.1%) of NbMoTaW RHEA [15]. It is confirmed that different alloying elements have different strengthening effect on the NbMoTaW RHEA. Some elements merely strengthen the alloy without any improvement of ductility while others enhance both the strength and ductility. However, the effect of alloying element on this alloy's mechanical properties, such as strength and ductility, is still unclear up to now, and needs systematic investigations. In present work, elements with high melting points over 1850 • C, such as Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re, were employed to alloy the NbMoTaW RHEA and improve its mechanical properties. The alloying elements with high melting temperatures over 1850 • C were merely chosen in order to not weaken the alloy's high temperature resistance. The mechanical properties of the alloyed NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were predicted by theoretical calculations combined with experimental verifications. The influence of alloying elements on the mechanical properties of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs was investigated at the atomic scale based on the bonding strength and electronic structure.

div.head: Computational details
div.p: First-principle calculation of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs was carried out using CASTEP [20,21] based on density functional theory (DFT) [22,23]. Fig. 1 is the alloys' models. Supercell models of 1 × 1 × 5 were established for all the alloys using special quasi-random supercell method (SQS) [24] and five atoms were distributed randomly. Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [25] and Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) function [26,27] were employed to portray the electronic exchange-correlation terms. The electron-ionic relationship was traced out using norm conserving pseudopotential [28]. The BFGS algorithm was used to solve the Schrodinger equation [29]. The convergence tolerances of energy, maximum forces, maximum stress and maximum displacement were set to be 1 × 10 -5 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/Å, 0.05 GPa and 0.001 Å, respectively. The lattice constant and density of NbMoTaW RHEA were firstly calculated to be 3.195 Å and 14.099 g/cm 3 based on the above models and parameters, respectively. The simulated data was close to the experimental results (3.213 Å and 13.75 g/cm 3 ) [13], demonstrating that the above parameters were reasonable.

div.head: Experiments
div.p: NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs ingots were produced by non-consumable arc melting under the protective Ar atmosphere.

Small pieces of raw materials Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Cr, Zr, V and Hf with purity over 99.9 wt% were selected and used. All the raw materials were cleaned, polished, weighed in atomic ratio and placed in crucible orderly. Ar gas with high purity was injected when the vacuum degree in the furnace reached 2.5 × 10 -3 Pa. All the ingots were repeatedly melted for five times in a water-cooled copper mold crucible in order to get homogeneous composition. The samples for mechanical tests were cut into pillars with the size of Φ5 × 8 mm. Before the compression tests, upper and lower end faces of all the tested samples were burnished and polished with different sandpaper to ensure the uniformity of tests. The engineering compression stress-strain curves were tested using electronic universal tensile testing machine (CMT5105GL, China) with the loading rates of 0.5 mm/min. Due to the small non-standard samples, extensometer was not used and the strain was

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Nine independent elastic constants of optimized suppercell model of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs. Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM, Phenom-World BV, Netherlands).
Hereinafter, NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were marked as X Cr , X Zr , X V , X Hf and X Re , respectively.

div.head: Phase structure
div.p: HEAs are normally reported to form FCC, BCC or HCP solid solution structures [15,17]. It is necessary to firstly investigate the phase structures of the alloyed NbMoTaWX RHEAs. Generally, average valence electron concentration VEC and atomic size difference δ were used to predict the phase structure of high entropy alloys [30][31][32]. They are described as the following formula:

here, c i , r i , r and (VEC) i are mole fraction, atomic radius, average atomic radius and valence electron concentration of ith component, respectively. Alloys forming single-phase solid solution are considered to satisfy the following criterions: a) FCC: VEC>8, b) BCC: VEC<6.87, δ<6.6% and c) FCC + BCC: 6.87 < VEC<8. Fig. 2 shows the VEC and δ of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs. As shown, all the values of VEC and δ are less than 6.87 and 6.6%, demonstrating that all the alloys form BCC single-phase solid solution.

In addition to the above empirical formula, it is also a common method to predict the phase structure of high entropy alloys from the perspective of energy [33,34]. The formation enthalpy E f and cohesive energy E c of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs can be calculated according to formula (3) and ( 4).
div.formula: H f = 1 N i (E tot - ∑ n i E i solid )(3)
E c = 1 N i (E tot - ∑ n i E i atom )(4)
div.p: where E tot is the calculated ground total energy. N i and n i are the whole atomic numbers in supercell and the mole fraction of ith constituent, respectively. E i solid and E i atom are the energy of single atom after single crystal's completely relaxation and the isolated atom of ith constituent, respectively. The value of E f and E c , as the thermodynamic index, are usually used to predict the formation of metallic compounds and stability of crystal. The more negative E f and E c mean the stronger alloying ability and the better crystal stability. Here, E f and E c of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were calculated and plotted in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, respectively. As seen, the calculated E f of BCC structures are all negative except X Zr RHEA, and E f of FCC and HCP structures are all positive, which means that BCC structure is superior to form for all the NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs than the other two structures. Seeing from Fig. 4, it can be seen that the calculated E c of BCC structures for all the NbMoTaWX alloys have the lowest value, which also implies that BCC structure is more likely to form than FCC and HCP structure. The results of δ, VEC, E f and E c show that these designing RHEAs are BCC single-phase solid solution. Therefore, supercell models of BCC structure will be adopted in the subsequent property calculations.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Elastic constants and modulus, as the important performance parameters, are the reflection of mechanical performance of crystal materials. Therefore, the elastic constants and elastic modulus of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were calculated to investigate the influence of alloying elements on the alloy's mechanical performance. In present work, the stress-stain method based on DFT was employed to solve these elastic parameters. The polycrystalline elastic modulus of alloyed RHEAs was acquired by Viogt-Reuss-Hill (VRH) method [35]. The calculated results were collected in Tables 1 and2. Nine elastic constants obtained by SQS method were averaged according to the following formula (5).

For BCC crystal, it has three independent elastic constants and they are plotted in Fig. 5. As seen, C 12 and C 44 of all the alloyed RHEAs are almost equal compared with that of the NbMoTaW RHEA. C 11 of X Zr and X Hf RHEAs are less than that of others. Commonly, there is a positive correlation between elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) and modulus (B, G, E). The larger bulk modulus B and shear modulus G mean the greater incompressibility and resistance to shear deformation when the loading is applied on the materials. Little changed G of NbMoTaWX RHEAs indicates that the shear strength of all the alloyed RHEAs is similar. Besides, the decreasing B demonstrates that the incompressibility of the NbMoTaWX RHEAs weakens. In other words, the adding of these alloying elements into NbMoTaW RHEA can improve its compressibility and ductility. Besides, the mechanical structural stability of the alloyed RHEAs under stress is also of great concern. The following Born rule is usually employed to predict RHEAs' structural stability [36]. Otherwise, the materials are considered to be brittle. Besides, the alloys with a positive C 12 -C 44 are normally thought to have metallic character. The values of C 12 -C 44 were calculated and gathered in Table 2. All the positive values of C 12 -C 44 show that these alloyed RHEAs have metallic character and intrinsic ductility. B/G and ν were also calculated and listed in Fig. 6. As seen, the values of the alloyed RHEAs are higher than NbMoTaW alloy, demonstrating that alloying improves the ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA. Different values show distinguishing enhanced effects.

In order to further confirm the alloying enhancement of the NbMo-TaW alloys, NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V and Hf) RHEAs were respectively prepared and engineering compressive stress-strain curves were acquired at the room temperature. The results were listed in Table 3 and plotted in Fig. 7. The illustration in Fig. 7 shows the compression properties of NbMoTaW at room temperature [14]. The compressive properties of NbMoTaWRe alloy have been reported by J. Zhang el at and their results were referenced [17]. As seen, the strength and ductility of the alloyed RHEAs were obviously improved. Compared with NbMoTaW RHEA, the yield stress of NbMoTaWX RHEAs increases by 10-66%. X V RHEA has the large yield strength and reaches about 1460 MPa. The peak stress is also increased up to 50% compared with that of NbMoTaW RHEA. X Zr RHEA has the maximum peak stress and reaches about 1822 MPa. From the stress-strain curves, it is obviously seen that the strength and ductility of X Zr RHEA have a noteworthy improvement. The peak strain of X Zr RHEAs reaches about 15.9%, much larger than that of NbMoTaW RHEA. The experimental data well agrees with the results based on the calculated elastic constants and modulus.

div.head: Electronic properties
div.p: The macroscopic mechanical performance of alloys is closely related to the electronic structure and atomic interaction to some extent. The difference of alloying enhancement of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs may be attributed to the difference of the electronic structure and atomic interaction. Therefore, the total and partial densities of states (DOS and PDOS) of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were calculated and plotted in Fig. 8. As seen, the curves of partial densities of states of different atoms obviously exist heavy overlapping, indicating severe electron hybridization and covalence in the alloy system [40]. The more flat and compact conduction bond in the high energy region indicates stronger interaction of orbital electrons after addition of the alloying elements into NbMoTaW RHEA. For NbMoTaW RHEA, the covalence originates from the hybridization of abundant d-orbital and few s-orbital, p-orbital electrons of Nb, Mo, Ta and W atoms. For X V , X Cr , X Hf and X Re RHEAs, the DOS is similar to that of the NbMoTaW RHEA. The more flat and compact DOS shows the strong atomic interaction. However, for X Zr RHEAs, the new, separate and thin valence bond in the low energy region was found, which was entirely from the contribution of Zr addition. It is considered that Zr-Zr metallic bonds were formed in X Zr RHEA. This may be the reason that the strength and ductility of X Zr alloy were greatly enhanced. Besides, the contribution of each element's PDOS to the RHEA's DOS is very similar, indicating that their overall properties should have little changes. Interestingly, it was found that the DOS of the alloyed RHEAs in the Fermi energy level were higher than that of NbMoTaW RHEA, indicating that their metallic properties were enhanced [41].

In order to further analysis the bonding characterization and ductility/brittleness of NbMoTaWX RHEAs, overlapping Mulliken population P and bond length (Å) of bonding atoms of NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were systematically calculated. Overlapping Mulliken population between atoms reflects the information of bonding atomic electron cloud overlap and the bonding situation [42,43]. That is to say, there is a correlation between the overlapping Mulliken population and materials' ductility/brittleness. Generally, the positive value of overlapping Mulliken population symbolizes the combination of covalent bonds. The greater magnitude is, the stronger the covalence is, and the weaker the alloy's ductility is. The positive P has a disadvantage in the ductility of the alloys. On the contrary, the negative value illustrates that antibonding will be formed and the repulsion between atoms will increase. These conclusions may help to understand the improvement of the alloy's strength and ductility. Therefore, the ductility and brittleness of RHEAs can be judged by degree of covalence and bonding type. Based on these considerations, the overlapping Mulliken population was calculated and gathered in Fig. 9. As seen, NbMoTaW RHEA only exist the covalent bonds and thus, it exhibits brittle behavior with very small strain in the stress-strain curves at room temperature. Covalent bonds are dominated in NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs system and meanwhile different types of chemical bonds were formed. The increasing number of chemical bonds type and more complex atomic interactions result in the decreasing covalence and the increase of the metallicity. Shortly, the number of antibonding in these alloyed RHEAs surpasses NbMoTaW RHEA. Compared with NbMoTaW RHEA, these alloyed RHEAs have larger strength and better ductility. Besides, for all the alloyed RHEAs, W2-Nb2, Nb2-Ta2 and Nb1-Mo2 bonds are less than zero, which means that these atoms no longer form the covalent bonds. They may relate to the metallic bonds. Therefore, the strength and ductility of these alloyed RHEAs were enhanced. From the perspective of overlapping Mulliken population, these alloying elements (Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) have the effect of strengthening NbMoTaW RHEA.

Additionally, the charge densities and atomic distance of NbMo-TaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs along the crystal plane (110) were calculated and plotted in Fig. 10. As seen, the charge densities contours show that there is a strong overlapping of electron clouds [44]. The results demonstrate that covalent bond is inclined to form in NbMoTaWX RHEAs. It should be noted that some Zr-Zr metallic bond are obviously formed in the X Zr RHEAs, which should have great influence on the alloy's properties. In order to confirm the bonding characteristic, XPS tests of the X Zr RHEAs were performed and the results are shown in Fig. 11. Fortunately, we can see that the Zr 3d peak gave two doublets according to valence, Zr 0 and Zr 4+ , indicating that Zr element existed as metallic and oxide states in a detectable depth with XPS [45]. The XPS results show that Zr-Zr metallic bonds were formed in NbMo-TaWZr alloy system, which well agreed with the theoretical prediction. The oxide states of Zr, i.e. Zr 4+ , may be resulted from the micro oxidation of Zr element on the sample surface during sample preparation or tests. In order to confirm this, cross-section of the samples was analyzed using XRD and SEM-EDS (Fig. 12). No diffraction peak of zirconia was detected in XRD patterns and no obvious oxygen was found in the results of EDS. Therefore, Zr element with oxide states should be resulted from the surface micro-oxidation during sample preparation or tests.

The atomic distances were also exhibited in the charge densities contours. To make better understanding, they are gathered and plotted in Fig. 13. As seen, for all the alloyed RHEAs, the atomic distance of these chemical bonds changes little except for X2-X1, X1-Nb1 and Ta1-X2 (X = Zr, Hf) bonds. Atomic distance of X2-X1, X1-Nb1 and Ta1-X2 bonds have a big fluctuation, and are much higher than that of other chemical bonds. This may also be the reason that the alloyed RHEAs have good compressive mechanical performance.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: The phase structure, elastic properties, and electronic structure of alloyed NbMoTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) RHEAs were predicted and the effect of alloying elements on the mechanical performance was investigated based on first-principle calculation and experiments. The δ, VEC, E f , and E c indicate that the alloyed NbMoTaWX RHEAs have a BCC single-phase solid solution structure. Most of the alloying elements (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) enhanced the strength of NbMoTaW RHEA, while only Zr-alloying improved both the strength and ductility simultaneously. The strengthening mechanism was well analyzed based on the electronic structures. The formation of partial Zr-Zr metallic bonds effectively improved the strength and ductility of NbMoTaW RHEA from the perspective of experiments and theoretical predictions. The calculated results are in good agreement with the experimental data, which suggests an effective strategy for the strengthening of the NbMoTaW RHEA via alloying.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Yonggang Tong: Formal analysis, Data curation, Writing -original draft, contributed the central idea, analyzed most of the data, and wrote the initial draft of the paper. The remaining authors contributed to refining the ideas, carrying out additional analyses and finalizing this paper. Linhui Bai: Formal analysis, Data curation, Writing -original draft, contributed the central idea, analyzed most of the data, and wrote the initial draft of the paper. The remaining authors contributed to refining the ideas, carrying out additional analyses and finalizing this paper. Xiubing Liang: Formal analysis, Data curation, Writing -original

figure.head: C 11 >
figure.figDesc: 0; C 44 > 0; (C 11 -C 12 ) > 0; C 11 + 2C 12 > 0 (6) After computing, the elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) are fit for Born rules, demonstrating that all the NbMoTaWX RHEAs are mechanically stable. Normally, Pugh's ratio B/G, Poisson's ration ν and Cauchy stress C 12 -C 44 are used to predict alloy's ductility and brittleness [37-39]. B/G > 1.75, ν > 0.33 and C 12 -C 44 >0, imply the ductile materials.
